disease: Merkel cell carcinoma of unspecified part of face

symptoms.name: Skin growth
symptoms.pattern: Most often the first symptom; can be a mole, freckle, or bump that changes size, shape, or color; may grow fast or bleed easily after minor injury

symptoms.name: Swelling
symptoms.pattern: May be present, as in the case report

symptoms.name: Erythematous plaque
symptoms.pattern: May be present, as in the case report

symptoms.name: Induration and nodules
symptoms.pattern: May be present, as in the case report

physical_findings: Rapidly growing, asymptomatic, firm, red-violaceous nodule on sun-exposed skin
May present as a subcutaneous nodule without overlying skin changes
5 × 3–cm nodular lesion on the right side of the cheek with swelling of the right upper lip (case report)
Erythematous plaque on the right upper lip extending to the nasolabial fold (case report)
Induration and nodules felt under the plaque (case report)

lab_values.Complete blood count: May show high white blood cell count, platelet count, and creatinine (case report)

risk_factors: Advancing age (most often in people older than 50)

required: Skin biopsy showing dermal proliferation of small, blue cells in sheets or a trabecular array; cells contain scant cytoplasm and round nuclei containing finely granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli; numerous mitotic figures are typically visible; tumor may demonstrate vascular invasion, perineural invasion, or cellular necrosis

Immunohistochemistry: positive for cytokeratin-20, neuron-specific enolase, epithelial membrane antigen, CAM 5.2, and neuroendocrine markers such as synaptophysin and chromogranin; negative for TTF-1, S-100, and leukocyte-common antigen
supportive: Clinical presentation: rapidly growing, asymptomatic, firm, red-violaceous nodule on sun-exposed skin
